stork.feather

Class Session<S extends Session<S,R>,R extends Resource<S,R>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • stork.feather.Session<S,R>
  • Type Parameters:
    S - The type of the subclass of this Session. This unfortunate redundancy exists solely to circumvent weaknesses in Java's typing system.
    R - The type of Resources handled by this Session.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FTPSession, HTTPRequest, LocalSession

    public abstract class Session<S extends Session<S,R>,R extends Resource<S,R>>
extends Object
    A Session is a stateful context for operating on Resources. Sessions serve as a nexus for all of the stateful information related to operating on a particular class of Resources, which may include network connections, user credentials, configuration options, and other state necessary for operating on the Resources it supports.

    Resources handled by the Session may be selected through the Session, in which case all operations on the Resource will be performed in the context of the Session. Whether or not a particular Resource is capable of being handled by the Session depends on the URI associated with the Resource in question.

    Sessions maintain state information regarding whether or not they are ready for operation, and can be tested for equality based the URI and user credentials used to instantiate them. This makes Sessions suitable for caching and reusing. A Resource selected on an unconnected Session can, for instance, be reselected through an equivalent Session that is still "warm", allowing the Session to be reused and the initialization overhead to be avoided.
    See Also:
    Resource

      • initialize

        protected Bell<S> initialize()
                                           throws Exception
        Prepare the Session to perform operations on its Resources. The exact nature of this preparation varies from implementation to implementation, but generally includes establishing network connections and performing authentication. Access to this method is mediated such that the implementor may assume that this method will be called at most once.

        Implementations may return null if resource does not require any asynchronous initialization. This method may also throw an Exception if it is certain that initialization cannot be performed for some reason (perhaps invalid input). By default, this method returns null.

        Returns:
        A Bell which will ring with this Session when it is prepared to perform operations on resource, or null if the Resource requires no initialization.
        Throws:
        Exception - either via the returned Bell or from the method itself if a problem occurs. Subclasses should only declare throws Exception in the signature if it actually does so, and should omit it otherwise.

      • finalize

        protected void finalize()
        Release any resources allocated during the initialization of this Session. This method should close any connections and finalize any ongoing transactions.
        Overrides:
        finalize in class Object

      • close

        public final S close()
        Close this Session and call finalize(). initialize() will never be called after this has been called.
        Returns:
        This Session.

      • isClosed

        public final boolean isClosed()
        Check if the closing procedure has begun.
        Returns:
        true if closing has begun; false otherwise.

      • onClose

        public final Bell<S> onClose()
        Return a bell that will be rung with this Session when the Session is closed.
        Returns:
        A Bell that will be rung when the Session is closed.

      • onClose

        public final Bell<? super S> onClose(Bell<? super S> bell)
        Register a Bell to be rung with this Session when the Session is closed. This is slightly more memory-efficient than promising on the Bell returned by onClose(), as it gets promised to an internal Bell directly.
        Parameters:
        bell - a Bell that will be rung when the Session is closed.
        Returns:
        Whatever value was passed in for bell.
